comments:
When running the automated debug tests on Linux gtk x86 (and ppc also), the tests
testExclusiveScopedException and testMultiExclusiveScopedExceptionMiss both fail.

These tests pass on Sun Java 1.4.2 and 5.0.  They also pass on IBM Java 1.4.2, but fail on Java 5.0.

The test cases time out after 30 seconds and then gives some console output.  For example, the console output on testExclusiveScopedException shows the following:

Test case: testExclusiveScopedException
Never received event: Terminate
Console output follows:


In the test report, this output is shown:

N/A

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.terminateAndRemove(AbstractDebugTest.java:1156)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.breakpoints.ExceptionBreakpointTests.testExclusiveScopedException(ExceptionBreakpointTests.java:131)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.AbstractDebugTest.runBare(AbstractDebugTest.java:1460)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.DebugSuite$1.run(DebugSuite.java:53)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:799)

This is because launchAndTerminate returns a null pointer.

These are the only two tests that fail in the debug test suite.

I will continue to look into this as best I can, but I am very unfamiliar with this code.

To help debug this problem, I added the following line of code just inside the loop of handleDebugEvents:

System.out.println("Event: " + events[i].toString());

This produces the following ouput on IBM Java 5.0:
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess@6b966b96, CHANGE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess@6b966b96, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]

Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread@4a284a28, SUSPEND, BREAKPOINT]

Test case: testExclusiveScopedException
Never received event: Terminate
Console output follows:

On IBM Java 1.4.2 I get this:

Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess@356ff9aa, CHANGE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess@356ff9aa, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.debug.core.model.RuntimeProcess@356ff9aa, CHANGE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread@304539ac, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread@797539af, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread@78f9b9af, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]
Event: DebugEvent[org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIDebugTarget@442b39ba, CREATE, UNSPECIFIED]

Event: DebugEvent[testExclusiveScopedException(org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.breakpoints.ExceptionBreakpointTests), MODEL_SPECIFIC, UNSPECIFIED]

One notable difference is that there's an extra thread creation event in the Java 5.0 event list.  I have no idea why this would be or whether even this has anything to do with the problem.

I'm hoping this might ring some bells in the head of someone who's worked on this code before.

what kernel and vm combination are you using?

we recently discovered a bug (153458) that would cause timing test failures and overall very poor performance using java 1.5 with certain Linux kernels.

I haven't noticed any significant performance problems.

On the x86 machine
------------------
Here's the output of java -version:

java version "1.5.0"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build pxi32dev-20060511 (SR2))

Linux elm3b18 2.6.16.18-1.8-ppc64 #1 SMP Tue Jun 6 13:22:03 UTC 2006 ppc64 ppc64 ppc64 GNU/Linux

The breakpoint is actually working as expected - but we did not expect the class libraries to stop at an NPE while running our test code. We can alter the test to use a different exception, which seems to avoid the problem.

Hi Michael,

Thanks for looking into this.

Given Comment #5 , do you still think a bug against the IBM JVM needs to be filed.

If not, can you make the change to the test so that we can get a "pass" on it for IBM Java2 5.0?

we should do both :)

we will fix the test, and you should file appropriate bugs against the IBM VM.

Any idea why this is happening?  I haven't looked into it deeply yet.

I found that I didn't have the latest version of ProjectCreationDecorator.java.

With that change, all of the exception breakpoint tests now pass.

---
I will go ahead and post the bug against the IBM JVM.  However, my not understanding the problem well may lead me back to you again, Michael :)
hey no problem Corey, by all means just ask :)
